masters.name: Dale Carnegie
key_principles: You can make more friends in two months by becoming interested in other people than in two years trying to get people interested in you.
A person's name is to that person the sweetest sound in any language.
Talk in terms of the other person's interests.
Make the other person feel important—and do it sincerely.
Be a good listener. Encourage others to talk about themselves.
The only way to get the best of an argument is to avoid it.
daily_practices: Ask questions and truly listen to answers

masters.name: Robert Greene
key_principles: Never outshine the master.
Always say less than necessary.
Make other people come to you—use bait if necessary.
Learn to keep people dependent on you.
Avoid the unhappy and unlucky.
Win through your actions, never through argument.
daily_practices: Create value that makes others seek you out

masters.name: Chris Voss
key_principles: Empathy is not about agreeing—it's about understanding.
The fastest way to build rapport is to make the other person feel heard.
Labeling emotions defuses them.
Mirroring creates connection without effort.
Never be mean to someone who could hurt you by doing nothing.
The key to gaining the upper hand is giving the other side the illusion of control.
daily_practices: Mirror someone's last 3 words in conversation
Aim to understand before being understood

masters.name: Vanessa Van Edwards
key_principles: Charisma is a learnable skill, not a born trait.
First impressions are made in 7 seconds and are very hard to change.
Facial expressions are the most powerful communication tool.
Warmth + competence = the charisma formula.
Hand gestures increase trust and understanding by 60%.
Vocal power matters: lower pitch conveys confidence.
daily_practices: Triple your nods—it encourages others to talk
Make eye contact for 60-70% of conversation

masters.name: Mark Manson
key_principles: The only way to be truly confident is to simply become comfortable with being unconfident.
You are defined by what you're willing to struggle for.
Healthy relationships are built on boundaries, not neediness.
Rejection is just information, not a verdict on your worth.
Stop looking for the right person. Become the right person.
Vulnerability is not weakness—it's the birthplace of connection.
daily_practices: Express your genuine opinion, even if unpopular
Be vulnerable—share real thoughts and feelings

daily_insights: The person who needs the interaction least has the most power.
Confidence is not 'they will like me.' It's 'I'll be fine either way.'
You can't connect if you're performing. Be real.
The best conversationalists ask great questions and actually listen.
Your body language speaks before your mouth opens.
Rejection is redirection. It's saving you from the wrong fit.
People remember how you made them feel, not what you said.
Quality over quantity. One deep connection beats ten shallow ones.
Social skills are skills. They can be practiced and improved.
The most attractive trait is genuine interest in others.
skill_challenges: Start a conversation with one stranger today.
Give three genuine compliments to different people.
Practice active listening: don't plan your response while they talk.
Use someone's name three times in conversation today.
Make eye contact with confidence in your next interaction.
Ask follow-up questions instead of waiting to talk.
Approach someone who intimidates you and say hello.
Share one vulnerable truth about yourself with someone.
Attend a social event and talk to at least 3 new people.
Practice mirroring body language in your next conversation.
